content: Each state administers its own unemployment insurance (UI) program, which provides temporary ﬁnancial support to eligible individuals. In Maryland, this is referred to as the regular UI program.

metadata.section_title: General Overview of Regular Unemployment Insurance Program

content:
After you ﬁle an initial claim, you will receive a beneﬁt determination (in BEACON and through your preferred communication method, which you select when you ﬁle an initial claim).
Your determination will include whether you are eligible for UI beneﬁts, your weekly beneﬁt amount, etc. If you disagree with the determination, you may ﬁle an appeal. For details, see the UI Appeals page (at MDunemployment.com).

metadata.section_title: 2. How do I know if I am eligible?

content:
To be determined eligible for regular UI, you must:
● Be unemployed through no fault of their own;
● Be able to work and available for work without restrictions;
● Actively search for work; and,
● Have earned sufﬁcient wages in a one-year period (standard or alternate base period).
○ For the standard base period, we go back 18 months and look at the wages you earned in the ﬁrst year of the 18-month period.
○ If you are not eligible for UI under the standard base period, the alternate base period may be used. For the alternate base period, we look at your wages in a one-year period (the four most recently-completed calendar quarters).
NOTE: If you are receiving pay that is deductible from UI beneﬁts (vacation, holiday, or special pay, severance, retirement/pension pay, or back pay/damages), your beneﬁts may be delayed or denied.
See the Claims Filing - Initial Claims FAQs (at MDunemployment.com) for more.

Your weekly beneﬁt amount (WBA) is based on your earnings in the base period and ranges from $50 to $430 in Maryland. If eligible, you may receive up to 26 weeks of regular UI beneﬁts.
In some circumstances (e.g., working part-time while collecting UI beneﬁts) you may receive partial payments. Certain payments (such as wages, severance, etc.) are deductible from your UI beneﬁts.
NOTE: UI beneﬁts are taxable. You will choose to have federal tax, state tax, both, or no taxes withheld from your UI beneﬁts (when you ﬁle an initial claim). You can also update your withholding status in BEACON.

metadata.section_title: 4. What are Maryland’s regular UI requirements?

content: A weekly claim certiﬁcation is your request to be paid UI beneﬁts for a particular week of unemployment. You may ﬁle via:

metadata.section_title: 5. How do I ﬁle a weekly claim certiﬁcation?

content:
To fulﬁll the work search requirements, you must:
|
● register in the Maryland Workforce Exchange (MWE) system (mwejobs.maryland.gov);
● upload or create a résumé in MWE, make the résumé viewable to employers, and maintain an up-to-date résumé;
○ After you register, check your MWE inbox frequently for weekly tasks you are required to complete. Failure to complete these tasks may result in a delay or denial of your UI beneﬁts.
● complete at least three valid reemployment activities each week, which must include at least one job contact (see Valid Reemployent Activities for Claimants page at MDunemployment.com); and,
○ keep a detailed weekly record of all completed job contacts and reemployment activities. You are strongly urged to use the MWE Job Contact and Reemployment Activity Log to keep this record.
○ Detailed work search instructions are available on the Maryland Work Search Requirements page (at MDunemployment.com).
See the Information for New Claimants page (at MDunemployment.com) to learn more. For questions, call 667-207-6520 (Monday to Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.).
Maryland Labor - DUI Communications
3
